summary: This document is an email forwarded to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) from an anonymous individual claiming to be a previously unknown victim of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. The writer, a lifelong model, offers information about Maxwell and identifies Jean Luc Brunel as a central, more severe figure in international sex trafficking.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Identified by the email writer as a perpetrator from whom the writer was a victim, though described as less severe than Jean Luc Brunel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of the writer being a victim of 'MAXWELL/Epstein'.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Identified by the writer as Epstein's partner, the writer's former agent, and described as '100x worse than Maxwell' and a man who trafficked women internationally for 40 years.

connections.description: The writer identifies as a victim of both, linking them together as perpetrators.
The writer describes Brunel as 'Epstein's partner'.
Both are implicated by the writer as part of the same network of abuse and trafficking.
The writer states Brunel was their agent and implies victimization by him as part of a trafficking network.

events.title: Victim Outreach to US Attorney
events.description: An anonymous individual sends an email to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, identifying themselves as a previously unknown victim of Maxwell and Epstein and offering information.

keyFacts: An anonymous lifelong model and former teen runaway contacted prosecutors in November 2021, identifying as a previously unknown victim of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.
The writer claims to have social and professional connections to the network, having been at parties with them and having Jean Luc Brunel as her agent.
Jean Luc Brunel is characterized by the writer as Epstein's partner and a far more severe figure than Maxwell, responsible for international sex trafficking of women for 40 years.
The correspondence represents a potential new source of victim testimony and information for investigators years after the main cases became public.
